questions.text: A 14 month old child has steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following is true? All live vaccines can be given Only killed vaccines should be given Sibling should not be given OPV Pneumococcal Vaccine should be given before commencing the treatment Select the correct answer from the given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B,C,D Avoid all live vaccines in children with nephrotic syndrome until daily prednisolone dose < 1 mg/kg/day or alternate day steroid dose 2 mg/kg; and in children on cyclophosphamide or cyclosporine type medications. Killed vaccines can be given safely Age appropriate pneumococcal and flu vaccines given Avoid transmissible live vaccines eg OPV in the sibling no need to modify immunization schedule in patients who are taking inhaled steroids.

Highyeild:

Nephrotic syndrome is classified based on response to steroid therapy into the steroid-sensitive and steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. About 20% of nephrotic syndrome are steroid- Mutations in several genes are known to cause steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome; among the implicated genes, NPHS2 appears to be the most common known form of inherited steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, accounting for about 45-55% of familial forms and 8-20% of sporadic forms of the disease.

Extraedge:

The main features of nephrotic syndrome include: Proteinuria: Large amounts of protein (mainly albumin) leak into the urine due to damage to the glomeruli (the filtering units of the kidneys). Hypoalbuminemia: Loss of protein leads to low levels of albumin in the blood, causing a decrease in oncotic pressure and fluid accumulation in tissues (edema). Edema : The accumulation of fluid in various parts of the body, commonly noticed as swollen ankles, legs, and around the eyes (periorbital edema). Hyperlipidemia: There is an increase in blood cholesterol and triglyceride levels due to altered lipid metabolism. Hematuria : In some cases, red blood cells may also leak into the urine, causing hematuria (blood in the urine). Fatigue and malaise: Low albumin levels and fluid shifts can lead to fatigue and a general feeling of unwellness.

questions.text: MATCH THE FOLLOWING APPROPRIATELY a. Urine bag b. Nasogastric tube c. Suction cannula d. Underwater seal bag Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-1, b-4, c-2, d-3.

Highyeild:

Indications of underwater seal drainage : Pneumothorax (spontaneous, tension, iatrogenic, traumatic) Pleural collection - Pus ( empyema), blood ( hemothorax), chyle ( chylothorax) Malignant effusions (pleurodesis) Postoperative Thoracotomy Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) The suction cannula obtains a histologic sample from the endometrium on an outpatient basis, usually without anesthesia. It is also used for aspiration of secretion intraoperatively (to clear the surgical field) or for cyst aspiration.

Table:

#MANTRA Medical Item Description Usage Urine bag Collects urine from patients who cannot control their bladder function. Monitors urine output and manages urinary incontinence. Nasogastric tube A flexible tube inserted through the nose into the stomach for nutrition or medication. Delivers nutrition, medications, or removes stomach contents. Suction cannula Medical instrument used for suctioning fluids or debris from the airway or body cavities. Clears airways during surgeries or in patients with secretions. Underwater seal bag Sterile bag with fluid placed underwater to create a seal in chest drainage systems. Drains air or fluid from the chest cavity after certain surgeries.

questions.text: Which intrauterine infection is commonly associated with hydrocephalus? VZV Syphilis Toxoplasmosis Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2 and 3 only Several viral, bacterial, and parasitic illnesses are associated with alterations in fetal brain structural anomalies including brain calcifications and hydrocephalus. The process of infection can further activate inflammatory pathways causing the release of various Proinflammatory biomarkers and histological changes consistent with an infectious intrauterine environment (chorioamnionitis) or umbilical cord (funisitis).

Highyeild:

Hydrocephalus is the buildup of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain's ventricles, causing increased intracranial pressure. It can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired later in life due to various factors. Symptoms include enlarged head size (in infants), headaches, vomiting, and cognitive issues. Diagnosis involves medical history, physical examination, and imaging tests (MRI or CT scans). Treatment options include shunt placement or endoscopic ventriculostomy. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial for better outcomes.

Extraedge:

Hydrocephalushas been divided into obstructive (also called non-communicating) or non-obstructive (also called communicating) hydrocephalus. Traditionally, obstruction to the Cerebrospinal Fluid flow within the ventricular system has been associated with obstructive or non-communicating hydrocephalus while impairment of circulation through the subarachnoid space (for example due to obliteration of subarachnoid cisterns) or defective absorption in the venous system has been associated with non-obstructive or communicating hydrocephalus. The aqueduct is the most common site of intraventricular blockade of Cerebrospinal Fluid flow; with causes of obstruction being congenital or acquired. Congenital aqueductal stenosis is one of the most common causes of o bstructive hydrocephalus in children. Infections such as mumps and toxoplasmosis are acquired causes of aqueductal stenosis in children and can also lead to obstructive hydrocephalus. Diagnosis should be made by measurement of head circumference (particularly in infants), USG (mainly when the anterior fontanelle is open), CT and MRI. Although CT can demonstrate ventricular dilatation, it may further be required to identify the nature of the obstruction, either functionally or anatomically. MRI is the best imaging modality to provide such functional and anatomic information. Two recent techniques for decompressing the ventricles are third ventriculostomy and cannulation of the aqueduct.

Table:

#MANTRA Some CNS complications of different infections Viral Enterovirus Hydrocephalus Varicella zoster Hydrocephalus, microcephaly, brain atrophy, porencephaly, hydranencephaly, calcifications, polymicrogyria, and focal lissencephaly secondary to necrotizing encephalitis Bacterial Syphilis Hydrocephalus Rubella Extensive cerebral cortical calcifications, microcephaly, subependymal cysts Parasitic Toxoplasmosis Diffuse calcifications in the basal ganglia, periventricular calcifications, progressive hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following can be seen in this child? Bilious vomiting Visible peristalsis from left to right Palpable mass Hypochloremia and hypokalemia Metabolic alkalosis Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, 4 & 5 Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:- Causes gastric outlet obstruction in infants (1:600). Blockage of the passage out of the stomach due to thickening (hypertrophy) of the muscle at the junction between the stomach and the intestines. The thickened muscle creates a partial blockage (obstruction) that interferes with the passage of stomach contents into the small intestine. It usually presents between 2-6 weeks age. Palpable olive-shaped mass in epigastric region or right side below the liver Visible peristaltic waves from left to right, and non-bilious projectile vomiting after feeds. More common in first born males associated with exposure to macrolides. Results in hypokalemic hypochloremia metabolic alkalosis (2° to vomiting of gastric acid and subsequent volume contraction).

Highyeild:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition where the muscle surrounding the pylorus (the lower part of the stomach) becomes thickened, leading to narrowing and obstruction. Commonly seen in infants, typically between 2 to 8 weeks of age. Key clinical features include projectile, non-bilious vomiting, visible peristalsis ("olive sign") from left to right in the upper abdomen, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region. Prolonged vomiting can cause hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with associated hypokalemia due to loss of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and potassium (K+) from gastric contents. The diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound imaging. Treatment usually involves surgical intervention with a pyloromyotomy to relieve the obstruction and restore normal gastric emptying.

Extraedge:

Ultrasound shows thickened and lengthened pylorus. Treatment: surgical incision of pyloric muscles (pyloromyotomy).

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the initial treatment plan for this child?

options.label: D
options.text: Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.correct_answer: D. Bell and pad based classical conditioning
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bell and pad based classical conditioning Enuresis: Normally diagnosed if a child continues bedwetting even after 5 years of age (most children attain complete bladder control by 5 years) Treatment First-line treatment: Lifestyle modification (eg, scheduled voids, evening fluid restriction, restricted intake of caffeine and sweet items specially in evening); conditioning (bed-alarm therapy) and motivational therapy Pharmacological treatment- not first line: oral desmopressin (ADH analog); second-line pharmacological therapy is anticholinergic drugs such as tolterodine; and third-line pharmacological therapy is imipramine Bladder training with holding urine for longer periods during daytime has not shown any benefits.

Highyeild:

Bell and pad based classical conditioning Involves a pad with an alarm connected to it The alarm sounds when the pad becomes wet, waking the child up Helps the child associate the sensation of a full bladder with waking up to use the toilet Non-invasive and effective in promoting bladder control during sleep Emotional support is also essential for addressing any psychological factors

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: Uses a medication called imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant. Effective but has side effects and requires monitoring. OPTION B. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Explores emotional and psychological factors contributing to bedwetting. Helpful in some cases, but not always the first-line treatment. OPTION C. Bladder training: Teaches the child to be aware of bladder sensations and delay urination. Effective, especially for overactive bladders or urgency.

Extraedge:

12 has shown to be effective in treating bed-wetting in many children, promoting self-awareness and bladder control during sleep. Non-Invasive and Safe: This treatment approach is non-invasive and safe for children, making it a favorable option for managing bed-wetting without the use of medications. Supportive Approach: In addition to the treatment, providing emotional support and reassurance to the child is important to address any psychological factors that might contribute to the bed-wetting issue.
